There is reason to be optimistic that  volumes will be robust, with in excess of £m of deals expected to complete in the first quarter of .”LSH#s Investment Transactions Northern Ireland Bulletin detailed how £m had been spent on office acquisitions in , however the sale of the Merchant Square office development in Belfast - which went for £m - accounted for most of that sum. Across all asset types, the volume of deals completed in  was treble that of .Looking at shopping centres and retail parks, in , £m was spent in this area. This figure includes the £.m sale of the Lisnagelvin Retail Park to Manchester-based DS Properties, and the David Samuel Properties purchase of Shane Retail Park in Belfast for £m.Overseas investment title: revellers enjoy first st patricks celebrations in three years
story: Lord Mayor of Belfast, Kate Nicholl, at the head of the parade. Picture by Philip Magowan   PressEyePhilip Magowan   PressEyeShaneen McAteer and daughter Sophia enjoying the St Patrick#s Day Parade in Belfast along with Toni O#Malley and son Ruben.Belfast mother Nolene with sons Reuben and Caleb.Belfast family Eammon and Karla Cregan with their children Kaitlyn and Kian.Renata Kalemba and Aga Haroun from Poland enjoying the parades in Belfast along with Leonardo and Amera. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueLord Mayor of Belfast, Kate Nicholl, at the head of the parade. Picture by Philip Magowan   PressEyeAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThousands gathered in Belfast city centre as the first St Patrick’s Day parade in three years brought with it a spectacular display.Many parents brought children to witness their first-ever parade, proudly waving green shamrock flags as excitement grew.Read MoreThousands flock to Belfast city centre for St Patrick’s Day celebrationsAlthough the rain started to pour just as things kicked off, Belfast Lord Mayor Kate Nicholl – who is seven months pregnant – quickly put a rain cover on her young son Cian’s pram before leading the parade out of the grounds of City Hall at pm.Huge floats, including a giant mechanical Irish wolfhound, were complimented by the carnival sound of drums and many groups of young people showing off their dancing skills.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseShaneen McAteer and daughter Sophia enjoying the St Patrick#s Day Parade in Belfast along with Toni O#Malley and son Ruben. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueShaneen McAteer and daughter Sophia enjoying the St Patrick#s Day Parade in Belfast along with Toni O#Malley and son Ruben.Organisers said the theme of the day’s events was, “We are all Patrick, we are all Belfast”.Moving along Donegall Place, the parade journeyed into High Street, Bridge Street and Waring Street before finishing in Donegall Street near Writers’ Square.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Elsewhere in Northern Ireland, parades also ed to towns and cities including Armagh, Downpatrick and Derry.Some of the families excited for the St Patrick#s Day Parade in #Belfast City Centre. @BelTel #StPatricksDay pic AgMkWu— Allan PrestonMarch , The pandemic saw parades cancelled across the entire island in March , and several families told the Belfastthey were overjoyed to be back.Toni O’Malley , from Loughbrickland, was attending with her -month-old son Ruben as well as Shaneen McAteerfrom Banbridge and her daughter Sophia .Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBelfast mother Nolene with sons Reuben and Caleb. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBelfast mother Nolene with sons Reuben and Caleb.Toni said: “It has been amazing to get out because Ruben’s a lockdown baby so I really wanted him to be involved, that’s why I went a bit crazy with all the decorations.”Shaneen added: “It’s just so nice after two years, everyone’s out here together and we’re ready for a good day.You just miss things like this so much, we’re all about the children and to have a great day like this is just so nice. It’s also lovely to see other families out and about celebrating.”Renata Kalemba and Aga Haroun from Poland were attending along with first time-attendees Leonardo, Amera and Aine.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBelfast family Eammon and Karla Cregan with their children Kaitlyn and Kian. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBelfast family Eammon and Karla Cregan with their children Kaitlyn and Kian.Renata said: “I love to see the parade because I haven’t been for nearly seven years.”Belfast mum Nolenewas also out with her sons Reubenand Caleb .I’m really looking forward to it. This is Caleb’s first parade because we’ve just been stuck inside because of Covid,” she said.Eammon and Karla Cregan from Belfast were out enjoying their first St Patrick’s Day with their children Kaitlyn and Kian.Karla said: “It’s just great to see everyone back out and celebrating, it’s just nice for everyone to be together again.”Eammon added: “It’s great, this is our first time out together as a family watching the St Patrick’s Day parade so it’s going to be a really good day.”Lord Mayor Kate Nicholl also welcomed theof community celebration.She said: “It’s incredible. I remember when we had to cancel the last one and just that feeling of uncertainty and fear and wonderingit was the right thing even to do. It obviously was, but who would have known that it was going to be another two years until we could have this “So it feels like we’re really coming through, a really positive day for the city.”She added: “Just look around at the colour, the vibrancy and the people in the city centre.“It’s been dead in the city centre for the last two years and people haven’t had the opportunity to come together and to celebrate very much. This is a really special day.”Of her role at the head of the parade, she said: “I’m leading the parade at seven months pregnant and I brought the pram so I wouldn’t have to dance.“No one warned you how humiliating it can be being Lord Mayor. You have to dance at every opportunity, so I’m just going to dance a little bit today.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseRenata Kalemba and Aga Haroun from Poland enjoying the parades in Belfast along with Leonardo and Amera. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRenata Kalemba and Aga Haroun from Poland enjoying the parades in Belfast along with Leonardo and Amera.In Dublin, it was expected that around , people attended the traditional parade with many more watching on live TV.The theme was ‘connections’, which celebrated people coming together through art and heritage.Members of Ireland’s Ukrainian community led the parade with Irish and Ukrainian flags held side by side. The international guest of honour at the parade was actor John C Reilly, who called it a great opportunity to “spread joy” during a dficult time in the world.Anna McGowan, interim director at the St Patrick’s Festival in Dublin, said it was emotional to see the parade .“It has been three calendar years since the last parade and there are so many people whose lives are about putting on a show, and to be able to do that this year, and to welcome people back on to the streets of Dublin for our national days, it is so emotional and so important,” she said.Related topicsSt. Patrick#s DayMore On St. title: shock as young derry workers lay bare exploitation by bosses and low pay rates
story: Young workers who contributed to a Derry-based survey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers.Councillor Gary DonnellyCouncillor Shaun Harkin FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueYoung workers who contributed to a Derry-based survey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers.Garrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailYoung workers who contributed to a Derry Trade Union Councilsurvey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers at a special meeting of Derry City and Strabane District Council.DTUC chairman Niall McCarroll said the survey did not make for easy reading.Feedback from more than  workers found % do not earn more than the minimum wage % receive only statutory sick pay, and % struggle with bills.Of these, % are on part-time or zero-hours contracts, face harassment at work, and do not have trade union representation.Hospitality worker Grace Ward , referring to a past job rather than the one she currently holds, told councillors: “Working in the hospitality and tourism sector, I was paid £. an hour with no sick pay, protections or holiday pay.Read MoreParents ‘staggered’ to find Derry crèche locked and children refused entry“I was employed through a zero-hours contract with no guaranteed hours, being sent home earlythe sht was quiet.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “So, even though I have been offered an eight-hour sht, in many cases I only got paid for five or six hours.”She said girls her age were “fed up with basically working for nothing”, and added her teen colleagues use the term “working poor” to describe themselves.Retail worker Cliona Collins said in the past she had worked for £. per hour, which did not make her feel valued.“I felt uncomfortable and pressured to ask customers to buy more and spend more...I was five minutes late I would lose an hour’s pay,” she explained.“The biggest issue for me and my friends who have a part-time job is the amount we get paid. It’s really demoralising.“I also have to get taxis to and from work, which is around a trip fare of £. It takes me three hours at work to pay for my travel with my shts on average being between seven and eight hours.”With the cost-of-living crisis, she said young workers feel they should receive a pay rise and get the top minimum wage hourly rate of £., as they work as hard as someone aged .Unison’s Saoirse Fanning said the survey findings around Covid were particularly concerning.Twenty-five per cent could not self-isolate, % couldn’t afford to, and % said their employer wouldn’t allow it.She added: “We have been fighting for our members to get paid in full while off sick with Covid- or having to isolate.“Some employers were only paying statutory sick pay, even though money was available from the Department for Communities to pay staff in full.” She said the privatisation of services meant front line staff were on “poverty pay and poor terms and conditions”.She called for a social clause to be included in all contracts outsourced to the community sector.Independent councillor Gary Donnelly said what he was hearing was “shocking”, and asked what council could do to assist.Ms Ward said workers doing the same job should receive the same pay rate regardless of age.Mr McCarroll said Derry suffered from deprivation and neglect from ious governments and it can’t be the case that the city progresses on the back of local workers getting paid just over £ an hour without sick pay.He suggested the council look at wage inequalities and exploitation, and that hospitality businesses should make their pay rates known on menus.People Before Profit councillor Shaun Harkin branded wages for teenagers “a disgrace” and said every worker should receive at least the minimum wage.He proposed initiating research to get an accurate assessment of pay scales across the council area. He was told a motion could be brought before the full council.Councillor Derek Hussey, who has been in the hospitality business since , said he was “really shocked” by Grace and Cliona’s revelations.“The figures you’re quoting, I wouldn’t have got away with back when I first started in the business,” he added.“At the weekend I had an event and had to bring in part-time workers. I can assure you that I had to pay well — well over the minimum wage in order to actually get folk to work.”The DUP’s Hilary McClintock said for someone to have to work for three hours to pay travel and to not have guaranteed hours was “exploitation”.Related topicsDerry City and Strabane District CouncilCost of LivingPeople Before ProfitMore On Derry City and Strabane District CouncilNI was Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailStormont is on course to waste at least £m — and perhaps as much as £m — over the next  years due to its failure to find a way to spend Treasury funding made available to Northern Ireland for subsidising renewable heat.As revealed by the Belfastlast week, £m has already been wasted in this way and there is no sign of the Department for the Economy producing an alternative proposal for how it can spend the money.However, new figures show the vast scale of the waste aheadthe situation remains unaltered. In response to a Freedom of Information request from the Renewable Heat Association— which represents most RHI claimants — the department said that it was now on course to underspend by around £m. However, those figures only cover expenditure until , yet the GB RHI scheme — from whose budget Northern Ireland’s share of money for renewable heat is derived — has been extended and will not now close until .Based on that longer duration for the GB scheme, RHANI has calculated that Northern Ireland’s underspend may be closer to £m.Read MoreCriticism as Queen’s University Belfast ‘spends over £k’ on Amazon during pandemicThe hidden RHI scandal of how Stormont wasted £m in green energy subsidiesThe department said that it “will explore the potential to utilise any available [Treasury] funds in support of alternative or additional actions to decarbonise heat”. However, there is still no suggestion that this work has reached an advanced stage nor even that it will be possible because the Executive remains unable to decide how to handle existing RHI claimants.Those claimants were promised unalterable payments for  years but once the calamitous scale of the RHI overspend became apparent, Stormont abandoned that promise and retrospectively slashed their payments, meaning the actual overspend was £.m.That decision made them far less well rewarded than their counterparts in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland, which recently launched its own version of RHI — putting Northern Irish businesses at a competitive disadvantage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Sources within the DUP suggest that the party is split on how to handle the situation. Former leader Arlene Foster — the minister who set up the disastrous scheme but then said she was “accountable but not responsible” for the mess which followed — had endorsed a policy of throwing all RHI claimants out of the scheme, paying them a fraction of what they were originally promised as compensation. Sinn Fein has also endorsed this policy, but other DUP figures believe it is unfair to those claimants who entered the scheme in good faith, took on huge loans at the suggestion of its minister and government officials, and who did not abuse RHI.There is another factor which might explain the decision not to spend such a vast sum of money. The retrospective cuts to subsidies which had been guaranteed were immediately challenged in court by claimants. However, that process has moved tortoise-like over the last five years and has not yet gone to the Supreme Court. That case is just one of several RHI legal actions, the outcome of which the department cannot be certain.It may be that its decision not to launch a new green heat scheme is a way of hedging against the possibility that the original scheme is reinstated and it faces a vast compensation bill.Whatever the reason, it is having an increasingly stark impact. As oil and gas prices soar, renewables are among the cheapest alternatives — but have high up-front costs to install, which is why subsidies are in place where across the UK and Ireland.RHANI executive chairman Andrew Trimble said: “If civil servants had not removed  words from the national legislation on renewable heat when the NI legislation was implemented, then today we would have a strong, sustainable, environmentally friendly renewable heat sector. We would be contributing to our pathway to net zero and have a vastly reduced reliance on fossil fuels — with their polluting emissions reduced by %.”He said that Stormont could solve the problem by reinstating the missing  words — essentially replicating the GB scheme, with cost controls, something he said “could solve the political problems that Stormont and the department have created for themselves and for the people of Northern Ireland”.Mr Trimble highlighted that in , a Commons committee inquiry branded the department’s actions “a raw deal”, but the department had repeatedly failed to help genuine claimants suffering as a result of their broken promises.Related topicsDepartment for the EconomyThe Executive OfficeArlene FosterSinn FéinClimate ChangeMore On Department for the title: hostages like nazanin zaghari ratcliffe face long journey to normality
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe and Anoosheh Ashoori arrive at Brize Norton, Oxfordshire  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe and Anoosheh Ashoori arrive at Brize Norton, Oxfordshire By Danielle Desouza, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailHostages face a “long journey” back to normality after being released, a charity chief executive said as Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe ed to the UK.Lara Symons, , chief executive of charity Hostage International, spoke to the PA news agency about some of the struggles the British-Iranian mother-of-one may face after six years in detention in Iran.The charity worker was reunited with her husband Richard Ratclfe and their seven-year-old daughter Gabriella on Thursday, having been released along with fellow dual-national Anoosheh Ashoori after Britain agreed to settle a £ million debt from the s."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_a-e-f-ace-fafafedb_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_a-e-f-ace-fafafedb_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_a-e-f-ace-fafafedb_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_a-e-f-ace-fafafedb_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Lara Symons  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueLara Symons Ms Symons said Hostage International has helped many “trauma hostages”, adding: “From that experience, we’ve learnt that this is a new journey. This is a long journey.“I think when people think about normal le, they think about the le that they led before and, sadly, to some extent, that is not possible.“You can’t go back to that because both you as a hostage and your family have been changed quite a lot by the experience.”Ms Symons said every hostage has dferent obstacles to overcome after leaving captivity, but in regards to high-profile cases, media attention will be one of the biggest struggles.The moment Richard, Nazanin and Gabriella finally reunited after  long years. This picture makes me so happy and so proud of all  of my brave constituents. Thank you everyone for your constant support for this incredible family. #NazaninIsFree pic KZYMtFEA— Tulip SiddiqMarch , “Obviously, people have been following some of these hostage cases for years and they feel, you know, part of it and it’s something they want to hear about,” she said.“But the families and the ing hostages do need time and space just to be alone and try to take stock of what’s happened and learn to be with each other again.”It is also harder for high-profile cases to dissociate themselves from “the badge of being a former hostage”, but some choose to embrace it to raise awareness on the topic, she added.Ms Symons said being a hostage can lead to people “changing their priorities in le” as they find joy in the small things, which include having a meal with their families.In the case of Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe, one of her requests was for her husband to make her a cup of tea, while Mr Ashoori wanted a beer.One of the founders of Hostage International, Terry Waite, was kidnapped by Hezbollah in Lebanon, while he was serving as the then-Archbishop of Canterbury’s envoy in .“He is a man of immense compassion and he’s brought that to the organisation… just wanting to help people who are going through dficulties and using his own experience of having been through it himself – that is what Hostage International is about, ” Ms Symons said.Speaking on Tonight with Andrew Marr on LBC, Mr Waite said he had spoken to Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe about dealing with le after captivity.He said: “I said, ‘Nazanin, when you come out, take it asyou are coming up from the seabed. If you come up too quickly you will get nitrogen in the blood and you will become seriously ill.“‘If you come up gently, one step at a time, then you will be fine. Make your statement to the press, get that off your chest, then go and meet with the family and then go away from all the enormous pressure that will be on her at this time.#” Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletter Receive todays headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter. title: increasing levels of covid driven by jump in rates among 30 49
story: A member of NHS Test and Trace collects a sample from a member of the public at a Covid- testing site in Bournemouth  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA member of NHS Test and Trace collects a sample from a member of the public at a Covid- testing site in Bournemouth By Ian Jones, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailRising Covid- infections are being driven by a jump in outbreaks among  to -year-olds, while rates are highest in south-west and south-east England, new figures suggest.Public health experts have warned the virus is circulating at “increasing levels”, with several factors likely to be responsible, including the increased transmissibility of the BA. iant and the scrapping of rules for self-isolation.All age groups and regions saw a rise in Covid- activity last week, according to the UK Health Security Agency .Case rates were highest in south-west England, with . cases per , people in the seven days to March , up sharply week-on-week from ..Our weekly #COVID surveillance report also shows that case rates are highest in the South West and lowest in the North East.For more information, read the full report:https:t.co VCoiZzCtz pic WlEYGQVgS— UK Health Security AgencyMarch , South-east England has also seen a steep increase, from . to ..Rates were lowest in north-east England, though here the number jumped from . to ..Within age groups, rates were highest among people aged - and -, at . and . respectively, with both groups seeing a sharp jump from the previous week.Case rates are based only on people who have a positive result in a PCR test and do not reflect the true scale of Covid- in the country.As many as three-quarters of people newly infected with the virus are likely to be missing from the figures, according to estimates published by the Office for National Statistics .But changes in rates among dferent age groups and regions can suggest broader trends in the population at large.New estimates of Covid- levels across the UK will be published on Friday as part of the ONS infection survey, which is most reliable measure of the prevalence of the virus.This week#s #COVID surveillance report shows case rates are highest in those aged  to  years old and lowest in those aged -.For more information, read the full report:https:t.co VCoiZzCtz pic BoMiBRZc— UK Health Security AgencyMarch , Responding to the latest rates, Dr Mike Gent, HSA Covid- public health incident director said: “Covid- is circulating at increasing levels and while rates of severe disease and death remain low, hospital admissions have risen. As we learn to live with Covid-, it’s vital that everyone keeps taking the necessary steps to limit the spread.“Vaccination remains our best defence against the virus, and it’s vital that everyone has had all their recommended doses. Please help reduce transmission by wearing a face covering in crowded or enclosed spaces, washing hands regularly, keeping rooms well ventilated. title: politicians from both sides of border tout for business as trade and tourism on agenda in us
story: Economy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurneyTaoiseach Micheal Martin. Credit: James Manning PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEconomy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurneyJonathan McCambridgeMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPoliticians from both sides of the border have been talking business in the US as a week of St Patrick’s celebrations continues.DUP Economy Minister Gordon Lyons signed an agreement with the State of Maryland, hailing Northern Ireland’s cyber security sector as world leading.In Washington, Micheal Martin said economic links between Ireland and the US were a “powerful two-way relationship”.Mr Lyons met with representatives from Maryland’s Department of Commerce and Department of Labor to strengthen ties under a joint cyber security memorandum of understanding, which aims to capitalise on the opportunities the sector offers to both economies.“Northern Ireland has a world class reputation for excellence in cyber security with specialist university research centres, innovative start-ups delivering global cyber security solutions and an impressive cluster of international cyber security investors,” he said.“This is why we are the number one international investment location for US cyber security firms, with Nisos and Agio just some of the US firms choosing to invest with us recently.”He also travelled to Washington, where he was due to hold a number of meetings, including one with US government energy officials to discuss opportunities around hydrogen.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He was then due to attend The Ireland Fund’s th National Gala dinner to engage with influential business leaders.Meanwhile, the Taoiseach met with a number of Irish multinational companies based in the US.He emphasised the business and economic links between the two countries.He said: “Today we have been concentrating on the economic dimension of the Irish American relationship, which is a powerful two-way relationship. We met with a number of Irish multinational companies who have a very strong presence in the US.“American multinationals have a very strong presence in Ireland. Ireland equally has a very strong presence in the United States.“At a conservative estimate, Irish companies employ about , in the United States and bring a lot of expertise to areas like food, le sciences, technology.”Mr Martin also met with representatives from small and medium-sized companies which are led by women and discussed better channels of mobility of workers between the US and Ireland.The Taoiseach later presented Science Foundation Ireland awards to John and Patrick Collison, founders of financial services firm Stripe.Later he was due to appear at the th anniversary of the gala dinner, with President Joe Biden expected to make an appearance.The event is expected to raise over  million for charitable causes across Ireland.On Tuesday night Mr Martin declared Ireland’s tourism industry once again ready to welcome visitors from across the world after Covid.Mr Martin was speaking at a reception hosted by Tourism Ireland at the Kennedy Centre in Washington before watching a special th anniversary performance of Riverdance.He added: “The beauty, the history and the culture of our island has long made tourism one of the most important parts of not just our economy, but also our society.“We have greatly missed welcoming American and other visitors to Ireland.“Before Covid- in , we welcomed over  million overseas visitors to the island of Ireland.“Now is the moment for us to again open our arms, to welcome visitors and to show you the extraordinary sights and experiences of a unique island.” Earlier, Mr Lyons attended a business breakfast in New York organised by Tourism Ireland, where he took the opportunity to promote Northern Ireland as a holiday destination to US travel industry professionals.The Taoiseach also mentioned locations north of the border as he promoted the island as a destination for visitors. “Tourism Ireland’s Green Button campaign is continuing throughout this year. The campaign champions our strengths and iconic locations, from the Clfs of Moher and the Wild Atlantic Way, to Titanic Belfast and the Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland,” he said.“Ireland is a wonderful place for a holiday.“The warmth and hospitality of the people still stands, our scenery is stunning.“Ireland stands ready to welcome back our friends from the United States.”Related title: £15m investment for rural development
story: OVER poundm has been invested in a number of projects across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area with funding provided under the Rural Development Programme.The cash was administered by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership with the Leader Programmersquos village renewal money supporting  projects, including the development or refurbishment of  community facilities, benefiting over , people.Stormont rural affairs minister Edwin Poots attended a recent event at Killeavy Castle in Newry to celebrate the success in delivering his Departmentrsquos programme which also created  new jobs.He congratulated members of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership for their work in delivering the programme, supporting village renewal and improving infrastructure.The minister also referenced his recent statement to the Assembly regarding Northern Irelandrsquos first ever rural policy framework.ldquoI want to create a new programme going forward that will be completely tailored to our own unique circumstances in Northern Ireland, he explained.ldquoThe framework will see a new rural business and community investment programme that will cover the next seven years and will support my Departmentrsquos vision of putting sustainability at the heart of a living, working, active landscape valued by everyone.In addition, Mr Poots said the new framework will also demonstrate his Departmentrsquos ongoing commitment to ensuring that rural communities flourish and prosper through continued support and investment in initiatives that will make a tangible dference to those living and working in rural areas.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew, chairwoman of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Partnership, said the delivery of the programme has brought ldquosignicant benefits to the rural dwellers of Newry, Mourne and Down and is testament to the dedication of the Local Action Group.She added: ldquoThe knowledge of the members has ensured projects of high quality have been supported, which have positively impacted on the lives of the rural dwellers.Council chairwoman, Cathy Mason, said the organisation, in partnership with the Local Action Group and Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, has been extremely successful in the delivery of the Leader programme.ldquoThe positive impacts have ensured a strong rural economy, providing dwellers with access to high quality community facilities, towns and villages they can be proud to call home, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Ambitious plans for Camino style walk  in Down District
story: AMBITIOUS plans for a major walking trail which passes through Down District have received a pound, boost.A key component of the planned Columban Way is to develop ldquopilgrimage walking such as that found at Spainrsquos Camino de Santiago and at many other trails across Europe, with the trail highlighting Northern Irelandrsquos ancient heritage, including major Neolithic and early Christian sites along the way.It has been confirmed that a pound, grant has made available by the David Cross Foundation to produce a business case with costings to identy and develop the Columban Way from Dundrum to the Saint Patrickrsquos Centre in Downpatrick and from there to Comber by repurposing and upgrading sections of the former Ulster Way which was abandoned in the s.St Columbanus was one of the best-known of hundreds of Irish monks following in the footsteps of Saint Patrick in bringing Christianity, literacy and learning to Central and Northern Europe in the sixth century.Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright mdash who is an enthusiastic supporter of the new trail mdash said ii took St Columbanus  years to complete the journey from Bangor to Bobbio in Italy and he travelled more than , miles, mostly on foot.He is leading the local aspect of the project alongside Charlie Reid from Bangor, with both writing extensively on walks around Ireland and are committee members of Friends of Columbanus. They are supported by Duane Fitzsimons, from Ardglass, who is a walking trails expert.ldquoThe Columban Way forms part of the wider European lsquoVia Columbanirsquo heritage trail supported and promoted by the Council of Europe. It traces the route from Mount Leinster to Bangor through eight European countries to Bobbio in Italy, explained Cllr Enright.ldquoIt is instructive to see how rapidly other countries have rolled out sections of the trail since  and the th anniversary of Columbanus. Switzerland, Italy, France, Germany and the Low Countries have demonstrated the ability to deliver that we can learn from locally.Cllr Enright praised the support of Ards and North Down Council which has already delivered  miles of walk as far south as Comber.ldquoThis -mile section of trail is designed to encourage more people to learn about the history of North Down and Ards, including the impact the area had in a European context through the links with Columbanus, he explained.ldquoOur big challenge will be to engage with Newry Mourne and Down Council to deal with their huge gaps in the Saint Patrickrsquos and Ulster Ways. These should link Downpatrick to Dundrum and Killyleagh, but still have not yet done so..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Women win yet again
story: BALLYNAHINCH continue their pursuit of a domestic double when they travel to Armagh on Saturday in the quarter-finals of the Senior Cup.Ballynahinch Women followed up their win over leaders Carrickfergus with a hard fought - victory over derby rivals Lisburn.The teams shared six tries with a lone Jane Patton conversion proving the dference between the sides on a dficult surface.Veteran centre Rachel Morton weighed in with two tries and Avril Sherlock was the other try scorer.Coach Sara Simms and her team will be pleased with the rate of improvement shown and will hope to keep pushing up the table during the final part of the season.The seconds continue to blood young players during their Second XV League campaign and had another emphatic home win on Saturday.Armagh were on the end of a five tries to one defeat and coach Davy Harris will have been pleased with the response his team have shown since their Townsrsquo Cup defeat at the end of February.James Martin, Matthew Cooper, Ben McMullan, Cameron McGaughey and Harry McCormick were the try scorers.Injuries and call-ups to the first XV squad have had an impact and there will be opportunities for young players to stake a claim for a place in the senior squad next season over the next few weeks.Marty OrsquoNeillrsquos fourth XV continued their red-hot  form with an excellent - victory over Harlequins thirds.They have a % record in their league section and face a crucial three-week period with home and away fixtures against nearest rivals Academy either side of a Forster Plate semi-final against Donegal Town.A fth XV squad with an average age of  travelled to Banbridge on Friday night and came home with a superb - victory.Tiernan Keating, Conor Spence and Sam Forbes made their senior debuts and  players had appeared at some stage this season for the club Academy side.They have three consecutive home games coming up, including a home semi-final in the McCambley Cup against Ballymena fourths.Youth training continues at pm on Monday nights.
